Its walls were built in the 1600s
when Protestant England was at war with

who hoped to ally with
Irish Catholics and invade neighboring England.
In 1688, Derry's walls were tested

when Catholic James the Second
battled Protestant William of Orange
for the throne.
James' Catholic army besieged the Protestant
stronghold of Derry for 105 days.
Thousands died from starvation and disease,
but the walls held.
An event still celebrated annually
and displayed in the Siege Museum.
Down the street, the Museum of Free Derry
